Urticaria, atopic and contact dermatitis |Item_parent_short=Hypersensitivity and mucocutaneous allergies in children and adults. Urticaria, atopic and contact dermatitis |Rank=A |Title=To know the clinical aspects of atopic dermatitis according to the stage and its evolutionary mode. |Description=None |Rubric=Positive diagnosis |Contributors= |Order=9}} File:Fig2 lichenification.jpg The diagnosis of atopic dermatitis is exclusively clinical ====The clinical aspects differ according to whether the disease is acute or chronic==== - acute phase: acute eczema. elementary lesions: erythema, oedema, vesicles whose rupture leads to oozing and then crusts, pruritus, crumbled contours (Fig 1) - chronic phase: erythematosquamous lesions and/or lichenification (thickening of the skin - irregular squared appearance) (Fig 2 : lichenification)
===='''The location of the lesions varies according to age:'''==== - Infant: starts on the face and scalp and extends to the sides of the limbs and trunk; area under the nappy and mid-face area (nose) spared. - Early childhood: localised in the flexion creases of the limbs (knees, elbows++) and often the ankles. - older children: frequent lichenification induced by chronic scratching. - adolescents and adults: face and neck++ with rare but typical localisations: lips (atopic cheilitis), eyelids with sometimes ophthalmological complications (keratitis, keratoconjunctivitis), lower limbs (lichenification, prurigo).
====Development==== AD most often begins in the first 12 months of life. It usually develops in winter flare-ups, but can develop continuously (severe form). Improvement or even "cure" occurs in childhood, but 3 to 5% of children progress to an adult form, particularly those with a severe form. [File:Fig 1 lésions vésiculeuses.jpg|vignette|DA aigue]] It should be noted that a late onset in adulthood is possible but rare. It is a diagnosis of elimination which should lead to a search for other pathologies, in particular: scabies, contact eczema, cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, etc.

question.question: What is the primary characteristic of atopic dermatitis in children?
question.option_a: It is a chronic condition that typically affects infants.
question.option_b: It is a condition that typically affects adults.
question.option_c: It is a condition that can occur at any age.
question.option_d: It is a condition that is characterized by pruritus and lichenification.
